body: I didn't implement it, I just moved the regular expression to be outside the method (so that it's compiled only once). I don't know why capital letters are not allowed.

It looks like KAFKA-2272 changed this for Endpoint.java, so this change makes them match. There are some other differences in the reqex too. Perhaps we should move them both to a common location so it's not duplicated?

@guozhangwang I reworked the timeout logic a little bit, but it's still pretty ugly. I also modified the structure of the poll loop in KafkaConsumer.poll to use a similar do/while pattern since I noticed that the current behavior would result in delays of up to 1ms even when the passed timeout is 0. I wonder if that was the cause of the delays that you and Yasu had seen before.

Thanks for finding the bug! LGTM.

@guozhangwang wrote:

> What situations do you think is most cumbersome for existing producer partitioner?

IMO, the global partitioner is fairly clunky, cumbersome, and non-intuitive. First, apps and services using the normal (new) Kafka producer can specify the partition number when they produce a record. And when they do, the global partitioner never really is involved. In that sense, the "global partitioner" really doesn't seem very global; it seems more like a "default partitioner" called only when needed.

Any time you're using stateful processors, you have to at least think about a partitioning strategy, and more often than not you will have to define and use one. Kafka proper had no support for stateful processing, and thus sharing stream is perhaps more common. Stateful processing is a significant feature of Kafka Streams, so it may come up far more often and is thus more important to Kafka Streams.

Earlier you wrote:

> - The cons of using another partitioner inside KStream along side with Kafka produer's partitioner are that it adds another layer of partitioning on top of it and hence may confuse some users, ...

Yes, it does add another layer of partitioning, but that layer is specific to Kafka Streams. So for developers using Kafka Streams (and not Kafka proper) it is far more natural to define the partitioner on the topology's sinks. Developers who are learning Kafka Streams are likely to discover that `StreamPartitioner.addSink` can take a `StreamPartitioner` parameter, and when they do they may be encouraged to think more about partitioning.

Conceptually, a `StreamPartitioner` is more straightforward, too:
1. It has typed key and value objects.
2. The number of partitions is passed into the `StreamPartitioner` method. This is one less thing a developer using Kafka Streams has to worry about, even though the partition count is pretty essential for many partitioning strategies. In fact, it even hints to the developer that they may need to take it into account.
3. It's easy to understand how it's used. The nature of the topology ensures that any custom `StreamPartitioner` will only be called by the sink to which it was assigned, and the sink only handles messages that the topology's processors forward.
4. No need to worry about other topics, how the default partitioning works, or messing up one of the other topics.

> - ... and also is more vulnerable to resulted different partitioning schemes for shared topics from different processing topics.

I fail to see how the proposed `StreamPartitioner` is more vulnerable than when an application or service using the Kafka producer determines the partition number on its own. The bottom line is that _if_ multiple processors/services/apps are all writing to a shared topic, you _must_ make sure that they all use the same partitioning strategy. Period. Performing the partitioning logic inside a "global" partitioner configured in multiple processes is no better or worse than doing it programmatically within your code. In fact, one could argue that specifying it in the configuration is actually _worse_, because it's something that should not vary between installations (see [this blog post](https://blog.8thlight.com/uncle-bob/2015/10/30/futureproof.html) for details).

BTW, when developing this proposal, I looked for more direct ways a processor could specify the partition number, but specifying a partition number only makes sense when forwarding to sinks and in other cases any hint of a partition number messed up what is otherwise a clean API. I wonder: if I could have change the API more cleanly so that it was more akin to the Kafka producer API and let the processor set the partition number more directly, would there even have been a discussion about it conflicting with the global partitioner functionality?

I didn't find any other errors (in server, controller or statechange logs)

@SinghAsDev As discussed earlier, it might be a little cleaner to modify describeConsumerGroup something like the following:

``` scala
case class ConsumerSummary(
  memberId: String,  
  clientId: String, 
  clientHost: String, 
  assignment: List[TopicPartition])

def describeConsumerGroup(groupId): List[ConsumerSummary]
```

Then you could do any transformation in ConsumerGroupCommand.
LGTM
LGTM
LGTM. I'll merge, we can clean up the interface a bit in a follow up

@ewencp It will be a bug if the kick-out-of-group consumer can still commit offsets: their commit should be rejected with ILLEGAL_GENERATION. If you see this happening we should investigate this case asap I think.

About unit testing: I would personally prefer only adding test cases that are passing to the code base, and piggy-back tests that are failing due to some issues to the fix of that issue. But I also understands keeping track of those tests is sort of a pain: more painful it is, more motivated are we to resolve the dandling problem. So probably we should just eat the bullet and fix the related existing issue right away?

@guozhangwang The issue is with source connectors, which have to handle offset commits outside the normal consumer group offset commit functionality since they do not use topic partitions or integer offsets. So this issue is definitely due to the fact that we have not generalized a mechanism for having the group coordinator manage these types of write/commit operations in a more general manner. I thought about routing all these writes through the leader, but that only reduces, not removes, the issue since the lagging node could be the leader.

Re: tests, yes, I am looking to fix them immediately, so in this case we can defer for a while at least. I guess part of my point is that in general system tests are a lot more finicky than unit tests, so even if it's been reviewed and passes regularly locally, we can still see cases where it fails (especially for new functionality like this!). So even when we think the test is stable, we still might want a mechanism to put it into "trial mode" for awhile. But that's a longer term discussion, we don't have to address it right now.
LGTM :)
@ewencp Addressed your comments, sorted out failures, added more test cases

@guozhangwang Have a look and let me know what you think. I created two new exceptions: InvalidOffsetException and CommitFailedException. The first of these is an abstract class which NoOffsetForPartition and OffsetOutOfRange extend. The second is used for cases where the commit cannot be retried because of a rebalance (previously we threw IllegalGeneration and UnknownMember exceptions directly). I also had some very small fixes in GroupCoordinator and GroupMetadataManager which are hopefully not controversial.
@gwenshap @hachikuji my apologies for getting to this a bit late, I have addressed your concern in #442 . Thanks!
@SinghAsDev Thanks for following up! LGTM.

This JIRA is just to avoid users getting weird exception, instead of usage info, when none of topic or whitelist or blacklist is specified. Even if we support whitelist for new consumer, this issue will still be there.

@gwenshap or @guozhangwang This one is a trivial conversion, should be an easy review.

@guozhangwang this should take care of your concern on KAFKA-2734. I like to keep separate concerns in separate commits, as it makes it easier to cherry-pick and follow. I hope it makes sense. Also, note that this branch already has KAFKA-2734, which is a pre-req to this PR, cherry-picked to help reviewers try out the changes locally.

A few general comments:

1) there is an InterruptedException in common errors that are only used by producer, can we use it as well in consumer to replace WakeUpException?

2) Is SerializationException the only KafkaException that are not recoverable and hence will be returned to users in `poll`? Others may include InvalidRecieveException and SchemaException, and moving forward we may also have QuotaViolationException and BufferExhaustedException (once we have memory management on consumer). So the current list does not cover all the possible KafkaExceptions.

I am wondering if we could make the JavaDocs as:

@throws KafkaException for any non-recoverable errors while fetching from Kafka. Possible KafkaExceptions include:
    1) Wakeup / Interrupt ...
    2) Authorization ...
    3) InvalidOffset ...

And in future we may add 4) BufferExhausted or 5) QuotaViolation. We can omit other non-recoverable ApiExceptions and KafkaExceptions as they cannot usually be handled programmatically.
LGTM. Thanks!
LGTM.

@guozhangwang Thanks for the comments. I think it's probably better not to overload the InterruptException in common.errors since it is tied to actual interrupt semantics. For 2), I'm ok with documenting the more general KafkaException as long as there is a convenient place to find the specific exceptions for each of those cases. Maybe we could use an `@see` reference under each option in the list?
@hachikuji Cool. Sounds good to me.

I'm going to have to update https://github.com/wushujames/copycat-connector-skeleton with these changes, as well as the changes from KAFKA-2764.

Unfortunately, since I basically copy/pasted the File connector files into my skeleton, there's no "history" to show that they originally came from here, and so I'll have to apply the diffs manually to my skeleton.

@wushujames shouldn't be a bit deal, these are pretty minor changes anyway. If you want to make it clear, just mention the ticket in the commit msg :)

Glad you're updating this, it is a nice resource I can point people to when they want to get started writing a connector! We're trying to round out any final changes to APIs, but I think this was the last of it that should affect the skeleton project.

Yeah, I'm not worried. It's just another thing to do. And yeah, once the API is stable, I'll only have to update it if you change the API, and that would be infrequent (on a Kafka release boundary, most likely).

Perforce allows forking at the file level, and maintains history. So I can fork tree1/fileA to tree2/fileA, and then merge over future changes of tree1/fileA into tree2/fileA and it'll keep track of things. Kinda nice. Can't do that in git or mercurial, or at least I haven't figured it out.

I personally found the skeleton useful to create my MySQL connector! :)

@SinghAsDev It was sort of by design that we return the members in the group with empty data when the group is rebalancing. Maybe instead of changing this behavior, we can modify the AdminClient to check the state of the group before parsing subscriptions/assignments?

As @hachikuji said this is by design that we return the members with empty data. While for the solution I am wondering if we should patch `ConsumerProtocol` so that it will fill in the fields with default empty values upon getting an empty byte array.
Ping @gwenshap @junrao for reviews.
@guozhangwang Yeah, that also works. I wonder if the command line tools should be reporting the state of the group so that it's not confusing to see the assignments suddenly disappear?
@hachikuji Sounds good.

Hi @lindong28, thanks for the patch. Since avoiding duplicate LeaderAndISR requests can be tricky due to concurrent request handling and coordination of coordinator and replica manager, I would prefer to review and merge it after the 0.9.0 release so that we do not put any risks for the new release. Please ping me again after the release is out.
Thanks, LGTM.
